content: The Act may be cited as the "Y2K State and Local GAP (Government Assistance Programs) Act of 1999" and includes definitions. The "Y2K State and Local GAP Act of 1999" defines welfare programs including TANF, Medicaid, food stamps, and WIC. The curr_chunk provides definitions for food stamps, WIC, and child support enforcement programs under various acts. The curr_chunk defines child welfare programs, child care, and child support enforcement under different acts. The curr_chunk defines child welfare programs, child care, and Y2K compliance in information technology. The curr_chunk explains child care programs under the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 and defines Y2K compliance for information technology. Grants are provided to states to ensure state and local government programs are Y2K compliant. The Secretary of Commerce awards grants to States for Y2K compliance in state and local government programs. Priority is given to requests related to Federal welfare programs. No more than 75 grants can be awarded, with a limit of 2 grants per state. A maximum of 75 grants can be awarded, with a limit of 2 grants per state. Applications must be submitted within 45 days after enactment. A State Governor's Office may submit an application for a Y2K compliance grant within 45 days after enactment. The application must include a proposed plan for development and implementation. An application for a Y2K compliance grant must include a proposed plan for the development and implementation of a compliance program, along with a budget and funding source. An application for a Y2K compliance grant must include a proposed plan with a budget and funding source, as well as a description of a funding source for the plan's completion and system maintenance. The State awarded a grant must match $1 for every $2 awarded. The grant recipient must match $1 for every $2 awarded under the grant for Y2K compliance program development and implementation. State expenditures made after a grant has been awarded may be counted for determining if the State has met the matching expenditure requirement. In evaluating an application, considerations are taken into account. No grant awarded under this section can exceed a 2-year period. The Secretary of Commerce evaluates grant applications based on the feasibility and likelihood of achieving the specified purposes. In evaluating grant applications, the Secretary of Commerce considers feasibility and purpose achievement. Grants awarded under this section are limited to a 2-year period, and funds provided to States remain available without fiscal year limitation. States must submit annual reports if awarded a grant. The Secretary of Commerce must submit a report to Congress within 90 days after the termination of all grants awarded under this section, evaluating the programs funded under the grants. $40,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated for fiscal years 1999 to 2001 to carry out this section, funded from the Y2K Emergency Supplemental Funds.
